treatment.description: Roots not proliferous. Stems erect, unbranched; scales black with lighter margins, linear-lanceolate, 3--6 × 0.4--0.8 mm, margins entire. Leaves monomorphic. Petiole reddish brown throughout, lustrous, 1--12(--20) cm, 1/3--1/10 length of blade; indument of black filiform scales. Blade linear, 1-pinnate throughout, 5--25(--40) × 1--2.5(--3) cm, thick, glabrous; base gradually tapered; apex acute, not rooting. Rachis reddish brown throughout, lustrous, glabrous. Pinnae in 10--40 pairs, oblong to quadrangular, somewhat asymmetric; medial pinnae 4--15 × 2--5 mm; base rounded to cuneate; margins crenulate or ± entire; apex obtuse. Veins free, obscure. Sori 1(--3) per pinna, only on basiscopic side. Spores 32 per sporangium. n = 2 n = 108 (apogamous).

Blades pinnate throughout or pinnatifid only in distal 1/3, pinnae undivided to 1–3-divided.
Blades less than 2–3 mm wide, linear, frequently forking or with 1–3 small, narrow projections. 7. Asplenium septentrionale
Blades more than 10 mm wide, linear-lanceolate to lanceolate, if lobed, segments resembling adnate pinnae.
Veins anastomosing to form areoles; blades rooting at tip. 4. Asplenium rhizophyllum
Veins free; blades with apical buds or not but not rooting at tip.
Blades simple, linear to oblanceolate.
Blades pinnatifid, elliptic, lanceolate, to deltate.
Blades cordate at base; roots not proliferous. 5a. Asplenium scolopendrium var. americanum
Blades tapered at base; roots proliferous. 6. Asplenium serratum
Petioles 1 cm or less, dull; stem scales 0.6–1 mm wide, sparsely denticulate. 1. Asplenium dalhousiae
Petioles 1–10 cm, lustrous; stem scales less than 0.5 mm wide, entire.

Blades 2–4-pinnate, with only largest pinnae divided to all pinnae divided.

Delicate root proliferations usually present (commonly buried in mossy soil in crevices, but enabling clone formation); damp, shaded limestone; Florida.

Spores of different sizes and shapes, malformed (irregular in size and shape).
Blades oblong-lanceolate, mostly 2-pinnate; pinnae lanceolate to oblong-lanceolate. 25. Asplenium cristatum
Blades narrowly lanceolate, 2–3-pinnate; pinnae ovate to ovate-deltate. 31. Asplenium verecundum
Blades linear-lanceolate, s Florida. 23. Asplenium ×biscayneanum
Blades oblong-lanceolate, c Florida.
Medial pinnae pinnate throughout; pinnules mostly deeply notched apically.
Medial pinnae pinnate only in proximal 1/2; pinnules mostly shallowly notched apically. 29. Asplenium plenum
Buds at blade, pinna, and pinnule apices minute, scaly, dormant; Arizona. 27. Asplenium exiguum
Buds absent; foothills and mountains in e United States and s Rocky Mountains.
Petioles all pale green except at base. 28. Asplenium montanum
Petioles dark reddish brown.
Blades lanceolate to linear-lanceolate, 1–2-pinnate; proximal pinnae often somewhat reduced; e United States foothills and mountains. 24. Asplenium bradleyi
Blades deltate-ovate to deltate-lanceolate, 2–3-pinnate; proximal pinnae usually largest; s Rocky Mountains. 22. Asplenium adiantum-nigrum
Pinna pairs 1–2(–4); blades ovate-deltate, with fine nonglandular hairs on veins. 17. Asplenium pumilum

Blades oblong to oblong-lanceolate, to 20 cm; pinna pairs 4–8, base with or without small acroscopic auricle; on mossy limestone. 8. Asplenium abscissum
Sori 1(–3), mainly confined to basiscopic side of strongly asymmetric pinnae. 14. Asplenium monanthes

Blade apex prolonged into whiplike extension of rachis terminating in bud. 15. Asplenium palmeri

Pinnae ovate, oblong-ovate, to rhombic, mainly 4–7 mm, length 1–2 times width.
Pinnae oblong-lanceolate to oblong, mainly 6–10 mm, length 3–5 times width.
Rachises dark reddish brown throughout. 19. Asplenium trichomanes
Rachises dark in proximal 1/3–2/3 or only at base.

Pinna margins nearly entire or shallowly crenate-dentate; se United States to e Arizona.

Pinna margins nearly entire; sori supramedial; spores 32; widespread in s United States. 18. Asplenium resiliens 29. Pinna margins ± shallowly crenate-dentate; sori medial to inframedial; spores 32 or 64; local in se United States.
